Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's decision to reject the applicant's permanent residence application was reasonable and procedurally fair
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's duties were nearly identical to NOC descriptions, which led the officer to question credibility
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to provide credible evidence of work experience
Credibility_Factor: Officer doubted the verbatim nature of NOC description matching
Legal_Rule: Visa officers can doubt verbatim NOC descriptions; no requirement to conduct interviews
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for eligibility decisions; correctness for procedural fairness
Procedural_Issue: Lack of interview; adequacy of reasons provided by officer
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable decision and lack of procedural fairness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Job duties described by applicant compared to NOC
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA); Federal Court Rules
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged reasonableness and procedural fairness of rejection
Legal_Rule_Source: Federal Court jurisprudence on standard of review in immigration cases
Defendant_Response: Officer provided sufficient reasons and followed procedural guidelines
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of visa officerâ€™s decision
Outcome: Visa application denied; judicial review dismissed
Decision_Authority: Visa officer at Canadian visa office
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of visa refusal and grant of permanent residence
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to skilled worker eligibility and procedural fairness
Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residence under skilled worker category
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA s. 87(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Insufficient credible evidence of qualifying work experience
Applicable_Process: Economic class permanent residence application process
Governing_Rule: Visa officer guidelines on assessing NOC alignment and credibility
